update.description:
This is a follow-on to pull request #780.

After a little googl'ing I found the magic of [unitbuf](http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/ios/unitbuf/) which has solved the issue of flushing the stream with "\n" and/or std::endl.
update.title: Improve console output, fix for issue #794

pullrequest.title: Improve console output, fix for issue #794

content.raw:
I have narrowed down the issue by adding some tests to UNIT_Console_TEST in 1878672 (branch console_improvements_scpeters). There appear to be two problems:

1. gzlog messages with `\n` characters don't get flushed to the log file until a `std::endl` is received.

2. Whenever an `std::endl` is received by `gzerr`, `gzwarn`, `gzmsg`, or `gzdbg`, no other messages can be sent to that stream.
content.html:
I have narrowed down the issue by adding some tests to UNIT_Console_TEST in 1878672 (branch console_improvements_scpeters). There appear to be two problems:

  1. gzlog messages with \n characters don't get flushed to the log file until a std::endl is received.

  2. Whenever an std::endl is received by gzerr, gzwarn, gzmsg, or gzdbg, no other messages can be sent to that stream.

pull_request.title: Improve console output, fix for issue #794

pullrequest.title: Improve console output, fix for issue #794

content.raw:
I'm seeing a strange issue with some of the messages in the log file having multiple timestamps. It seems that a `gzlog` message that follows a `gzmsg`, `gzdbg`, `gzwarn`, or `gzerr` will have multiple timestamps. For example, running the Empty world tests from INTEGRATION_physics:
~~~
$ test/integration/INTEGRATION_physics --gtest_filter="*Empty*"
...
$ cat ~/.gazebo/test.log
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 3.0.0
Copyright (C) 2012-2013 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org


(1389228344 497016930) [Msg] Waiting for master.
(1389228344 505991478) (1389228344 506202435) (1389228345 437513895) World::Init
(1389228345 495411071) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
(1389228345 757637930) (1389228345 767018252) (1389228345 767199374) (1389228346 305966814)  debug physics:  iters[50] sor[1.3] erp[0.2] cfm[0] split[1] split tol[-0.02]
(1389228346 307479623) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, GetGravityMode returns 0 by default.
(1389228346 645062090) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, unable to respond to OnPoseChange
(1389228346 645108735) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, unable to respond to OnPoseChange
(1389228346 645378886) World::Init
(1389228346 656449844) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
(1389228347 19306929) (1389228347 28621111) (1389228347 28791193) (1389228347 548271132) GetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, returning cached value
(1389228347 887543670) GetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, returning cached value
(1389228347 887563458) SetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, caching
(1389228347 887681501) World::Init
(1389228347 917935761) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
~~~
In this case, after `gzmsg` messages, there are three timestamps, while after `gzdbg` messages, there are 4 timestamps.
content.html:
I'm seeing a strange issue with some of the messages in the log file having multiple timestamps. It seems that a gzlog message that follows a gzmsg, gzdbg, gzwarn, or gzerr will have multiple timestamps. For example, running the Empty world tests from INTEGRATION_physics:

$ test/integration/INTEGRATION_physics --gtest_filter="*Empty*"
...
$ cat ~/.gazebo/test.log
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 3.0.0
Copyright (C) 2012-2013 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org


(1389228344 497016930) [Msg] Waiting for master.
(1389228344 505991478) (1389228344 506202435) (1389228345 437513895) World::Init
(1389228345 495411071) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
(1389228345 757637930) (1389228345 767018252) (1389228345 767199374) (1389228346 305966814)  debug physics:  iters[50] sor[1.3] erp[0.2] cfm[0] split[1] split tol[-0.02]
(1389228346 307479623) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, GetGravityMode returns 0 by default.
(1389228346 645062090) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, unable to respond to OnPoseChange
(1389228346 645108735) Bullet rigid body for link [link] does not exist, unable to respond to OnPoseChange
(1389228346 645378886) World::Init
(1389228346 656449844) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
(1389228347 19306929) (1389228347 28621111) (1389228347 28791193) (1389228347 548271132) GetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, returning cached value
(1389228347 887543670) GetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, returning cached value
(1389228347 887563458) SetGravityMode [0], but physics not initialized, caching
(1389228347 887681501) World::Init
(1389228347 917935761) [Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:142] ServerFixture load in 0.9 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds

In this case, after gzmsg messages, there are three timestamps, while after gzdbg messages, there are 4 timestamps.
